From: "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...>
Subject: Re: How would novelty search best be applied to a virtual creature controller
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=YPxBAon4bZ8TSMhkpTTkai8kRacH-LhACd1ixO4eqTdmEBRFFRYX
X-Yahoo-Profile: kenstanley01

Rafael,

Like Joel said, I also do not think it is accurate to say that the=

objective function is embedded in the novelty function.  The novelty
funct=
ion may recognize the objective as different from other
behaviors, but it r=
ecognizes *many* behaviors as different, with no
preference whatsoever for =
any particular one.  Therefore, the
objective is not embedded.  

In fact, =
our argument is that, counterintuitively, embedding the
objective into the =
search (as fitness does) actually would make the
search less effective by s=
tunting its ability to reach the right
stepping stones.  The idea that "to =
achieve your highest goals you
must be willing to abandon them" literally m=
eans that there are some
goals that cannot be achieved if you explicitly tr=
y to achieve them. 
If correct, it obviously has a lot of implications for =
how search
should be run.

Also, let me briefly respond to your comment:

>=
 But anyway, I think the agent couldn't stop searching by
> itself when
> r=
eached the goal unless you told him to stop there, 'cause he would
> still =
try novel behaviors after that.

You may be confusing the agent "searching"=
 through the maze with
novelty search "searching" through different agents.=
  An individual
agent itself is not performing novelty search.  Each agent =
simply
follows a defined policy encoded in a NEAT-evolved ANN, just as with=

normal evolution.  So it's not like any individual agent is
continually tr=
ying to do something new.  Thus some agents certainly do
stop at the goal. =
 Rather, it is the novelty search (which happens
over evolutionary time) th=
at is searching for new kinds of agents.  So
novelty search may find an age=
nt who stops at the goal, and it may
find one that does not, but certainly =
some agents would stop, because
they are different from ones who do not sto=
p.  

So I'm just trying to make sure you are not thinking that the novelty=

search happens within a particular agent.  That is not how the
algorithm f=
unctions.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "joel278" <lehman.154@...> wro=
te:
>
> Rafael,
> 
> What you are saying is true -- if you are interested i=
n finding a
> specific behavior with novelty search, then you need to desig=
n the
> novelty measure so that the behavior of interest is distinct from
>=
 other behaviors. If the goal behavior is not differentiated from
> initial=
 behaviors than performance will likely be poor, because any
> navigator th=
at came close to the goal behavior would be *penalized* by
> novelty search=
 rather than rewarded (since this behavior would not be
> seen as novel).
>=
 
> So the novelty metric is very important when it comes to biasing the
> =
search, and should "recognize" the goal behavior and not conflate it
> with=
 non-goal behaviors.
> 
> For example, in the maze navigation domain, if th=
e novelty measure was
> "how much does a navigator rotate during an evaluat=
ion", then we would
> expect to find navigators with various spinning behav=
iors, but there
> is no reason to expect navigators to fully navigate the m=
aze; that is
> because rotation is not correlated with any exploratory move=
ment
> within the maze. In addition, a navigator that reached the goal (and=

> rotated x degrees while doing so) would appear the same as a navigator
>=
 that sat at the initial location and spun x degrees.
> 
> This goal/non-go=
al conflation is an example of harmful conflation, and
> a way of combating=
 it is to simply provide more information (or more
> relevant information) =
in the behavioral characterization of an
> individual. It is not always obv=
ious what the most relevant
> information is for a given domain, e.g. in bi=
ped walking, although one
> can usually make an informed hypothesis - for e=
xample, the final
> location of a biped walker after an evaluation may diff=
erentiate
> a successful walker from a biped that cannot walk (because a
> =
successful walker will travel further), whereas using the angle of a
> bipe=
d's head as a novelty measure will probably not be effective since
> head a=
ngle probably has no relation to behaviors of interest.
> 
> However, I don=
't think it is accurate to say that the objective
> function is embedded wi=
thin novelty search; novelty search searches
> only for novel behaviors, ig=
noring any notion of better and worse with
> respect to the goal. I think w=
hat you are saying is that you still
> have to have some criteria for termi=
nation (i.e. a routine that
> recognizes a successful individual). 
> 
> It=
 is important to differentiate an objective function that provides a
> grad=
ient towards *better* individuals that is used in typical
> approaches from=
 a binary "have we found the goal yet" function that
> does not actively bi=
as the search. One of the key arguments in the
> paper is that the bias of =
the objective function often keeps search
> from reaching the goal.
> 
> Jo=
el
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Rafael C.P." <kurama.youko.br@> wrote=
:
> >
> > But didn't the agent reached the goal just because the goal is ve=
ry
> > different from the start position? It's like the objective
function =
was
> > embedded in the novelty function. If the goal was similar to the st=
art
> > position in novelty space, it probably would perform worse than ran=
dom
> > search. But anyway, I think the agent couldn't stop searching by
> =
itself when
> > reached the goal unless you told him to stop there, 'cause =
he would
> still
> > try novel behaviors after that.
> > 
> > On Wed, May 1=
4, 2008 at 2:39 PM, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@>
> > wrote:
> > 
> > >   Pet=
er, there is no indication that the maze solvers produced by
> > > novelty =
search are any less "smart" than those produced by
> > > fitness-based sear=
ch. As we mention in the paper briefly under
> > > "Typical Solution," solu=
tions from both methods just go straight to
> > > the goal. In other words,=
 they do not take meandering paths; they
> > > take the most rational path =
and appear goal-oriented. So there is no
> > > discernible quality differen=
ce.
> > >
> > > However, it's an interesting issue because it gets to the
q=
uestion of
> > > what it means to be smart vs. lucky. In general, if an ani=
mal has a
> > > behavior that gets the job done consistently, one could say=
 the
animal
> > > just "happens" to do the right thing, or one could say th=
e animal is
> > > "smart." In fact, I think these are one and the same and =
the
> > > distinction does not really add insight into the inner workings
>=
 > > of the animal's mind.
> > >
> > > One of the reasons we get stuck on t=
he issue of whether something is
> > > "really" smart is because of the all=
ure of the adaptive
hypothesis in
> > > evolutionary theory: We try to expl=
ain everything we see in
nature in
> > > terms of some kind of adaptation, =
and as soon as you assume that
what
> > > you are seeing is the result of a=
n adaptation, you are
susceptible to
> > > the idea that it must be "good" =
in some way (which equates to
"smart"
> > > when decision-making is at issu=
e). Yet what novelty search shows is
> > > that a non-adaptive process can =
in many cases produce equivalent
> > > behaviors, which really turns the ad=
aptive hypothesis
upside-down, and
> > > makes the interpretation of the "v=
alue" of a behavior more
confusing.
> > > Yet at the end of the day, if it =
works it works, regardless of
why it
> > > became the way it did.
> > >
> >=
 > Anyway, so on the question of time series, I would not be concerned
> > =
> with this issue of whether it is really smart. However, another
> > > con=
sideration is whether there is sufficient domain constraint
to make
> > > t=
his search something other than exhaustive enumeration. Novelty
> > > searc=
h relies on the properties of the domain (i.e. the environment)
> > > to cr=
eate a useful landscape for the search. Something without any
> > > environ=
mental constraint may not make a good search space. So for
> > > example se=
arching through all possible pictures hoping to find Mona
> > > Lisa one da=
y may not be a good idea because just about anything
you do
> > > genetical=
ly produces something "novel." In other words, there is no
> > > "collapse"=
 of multiple genetic points into fewer novelty points (or
> > > more accura=
tely, there may not be cases of novelty points clustered
> > > closer toget=
her in behavior space than the corresponding genomes in
> > > genome space)=
.
> > >
> > > Still, I am not sure about time series, because the distribut=
ion of
> > > input precursor series may be thought of as a kind of constrai=
nt,
> > > since there are some precursor series you would never see. So it =
may
> > > actually work...I'm not sure, but it's an interesting possibility=
.
> > >
> > >
> > > ken
> > >

oogroups.com>,

 novelty search, it searches for new behaviors, right. But are

 "smart" in a sense.. For example, does the robot in the

periment succeed just because of luck? It is possible that a

ike a beheaded fly and reaches the solution by accident? How much

 same with fitness-based search? I am asking this because I am

neurons than the usual feedforward neurons that are

> > > > in

 > > most ANN models. The leaky integrators are better for precise

timing.

ing

ided, I do not
think I

e. non-leaky or

nges

com>,
"Kenneth
> > > Stanley" <kstanley@>
> > > > wrote:
> > > > > > > >
> =
> > > > > > > Hi Peter, that's a good question and of course learning to
> =
> > > > > control a
> > > > > > > > virtual creature with novelty search is=
 a complicated
issue
> > > > (and
> > > > > > an
> > > > > > > > appealing =
idea as well).
> > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > First, you have to deal with=
 all the representational and
> > > > > > physical
> > > > > > > > issues o=
utside of novelty search, like how many
inputs, how
> > > > many
> > > > > =
> > > outputs, and whether the body itself is not physically
> flawed
> > >=
 > in
> > > > > > > > some way (which is possible). As you are experiencing=
, the
> > > > > > > > inputs/outputs issue can be prohibitive even with fea=
ture
> > > > > > > > selection. It is also possible that HyperNEAT could be=

> > > > useful
> > > > > > > > because it does not care about the # inputs=
 or outputs
(and
> > > > can
> > > > > > > > potentially exploit geometric =
regularities), but
configuring
> > > > the
> > > > > > > > substrate then b=
ecomes the challenge.
> > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > Assuming all of that =
stuff is set up well with whatever
> > > > system,
> > > > > > then
> > > >=
 > > > > novelty search is a potentially winning approach. Yet
as you
> > >=
 > > > point
> > > > > > > > out there are some big questions there as well=
. In
fact, we
> > > > are
> > > > > > > > currently trying to provide the b=
est answers to these
> > > > questions
> > > > > > in
> > > > > > > > ongoi=
ng research, but some general principles might
help for
> > > > now:
> > > =
> > > > >
> > > > > > > > First, the archive in novelty search does not not=
 need to
> > > > contain
> > > > > > > > every point ever visited. Therefor=
e, it tends to grow much
> > > > > > slower
> > > > > > > > than the #of ev=
aluations. However, if it is indeed getting
> > > > too
> > > > > > big
> >=
 > > > > > > then it is not unreasonable to collapse some of the
archive
> =
> > > > > points,
> > > > > > > > although there is no standard method yet =
for how that
should
> > > > be
> > > > > > > > done. But we have reason to =
believe there will be
effective
> > > > and
> > > > > > > > simple ways to =
do that.
> > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > Second, the issue of one individua=
l looking different just
> > > > > > because
> > > > > > > > of a phase dif=
ference in effectivley the same behavior is
> > > > > > > > complicated. Fo=
r certain phase disaparities, the two
> > > > individuals
> > > > > > > > w=
on't look all that different, but it is true that at some
> > > > > > > > d=
isparity, they may look very different. Yet it is not
clear
> > > > > > > >=
 whether that fact is actually problematic to the novelty
> > > > search
> =
> > > > > or
> > > > > > > > not, because it would simply reward both types=
 of
behavior.
> > > > It
> > > > > > is
> > > > > > > > possible that the p=
hase difference is a result of some
> useful
> > > > > > > > genotypic chan=
ge, which could make it a stepping stone to
> > > > > > something
> > > > >=
 > > > better. Or, it is possible that it is superfluous
> > > > informatio=
n
> > > > > > and
> > > > > > > > simply takes some extra time exploring th=
e area around the
> > > > phase-
> > > > > > > > shifted individual. So it =
is hard to say a priori
whether it
> > > > is
> > > > > > a
> > > > > > > >=
 major concern. We will have better answers to such
questions
> > > > as
> =
> > > > > the
> > > > > > > > technique is further explored.
> > > > > > > =
>
> > > > > > > > However, I agree that it would be nice to be able to
say =
the
> > > > two
> > > > > > > > phase-shifted individuals are largely the s=
ame if that is
> > > > indeed
> > > > > > > > what you want to say. And for=
 that, you would need a
> pattern-
> > > > > > > > matching metric to compu=
te behavioral distance, i.e.
> > > > something
> > > > > > more
> > > > > >=
 > > sophisiticated than simple Cartesian distance. There are
> > > > > > c=
ertainly
> > > > > > > > such metrics available. However, it's important to=

recognize
> > > > > > that
> > > > > > > > it is not evident at this point=
 that ignoring the phase
> shift
> > > > is
> > > > > > > > actually better=
 than taking it into consideration, because
> > > > taking
> > > > > > it
>=
 > > > > > > > into consideration just means adding more information
to the=

> > > > > > novelty
> > > > > > > > landscape.
> > > > > > > >
> > > > > >=
 > > So overall I think novelty search is a very promising
> > > > directio=
n
> > > > > > to
> > > > > > > > go for such problems, but it is still in t=
he realm of
> > > > research
> > > > > > (i.e.
> > > > > > > > there is no =
existing precedent), so it will involve
> > > > considerable
> > > > > > > =
> trial and error to get it right until all these issues are
> > > > > > fl=
eshed
> > > > > > > > out more clearly. Ultimately, though, if our hypothes=
is
> > > > about

arch may
turn out
> > > > to be

in highly complex types of

me domains, which is a sobering thought.
